skill.name: building-logseq-plugins
skill.description: Expert guidance for building Logseq plugins compatible with the new DB architecture. Auto-invokes when users want to create Logseq plugins, work with the Logseq Plugin API, extend Logseq functionality, or need help with plugin development for DB-based graphs. Covers plugin structure, API usage, and DB-specific considerations.
skill.summary: Expert guidance for building Logseq plugins compatible with the new DB architecture. Auto-invokes wh...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only guidance text and code examples for Logseq plugin development. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file operations beyond reading the skill file itself.

content.user_title: Build Logseq Plugins with DB Support
content.value_statement: Building Logseq plugins requires understanding the Plugin API, DB architecture, and compatibility patterns. This skill provides expert guidance on plugin structure, API namespaces, Datalog queries, and DB-version specific considerations.
actual_capabilities: Guide plugin structure and file organization
Explain logseq.Editor, logseq.DB, and logseq.App namespaces
Provide Datalog query examples for DB version
Show slash command and block context menu registration
Explain DB vs MD version compatibility patterns
limitations: Does not write plugin code or create files directly
Does not interact with Logseq application or execute plugins
Does not install or configure development environments
Limited to guidance; actual development requires separate setup

use_cases.title: Create New Logseq Plugins
use_cases.description: Get step-by-step guidance on initializing a new Logseq plugin project with proper structure and manifest.

use_cases.title: Extend Logseq Functionality
use_cases.description: Learn to add custom slash commands, block context menus, and UI components to enhance your workflow.

use_cases.title: Build DB-Version Compatible Plugins
use_cases.description: Understand differences between MD and DB versions and build plugins that work with both graph types.

prompt_templates.title: Create Basic Plugin
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a new Logseq plugin? Show me the basic file structure and package.json manifest.

prompt_templates.title: Query Graph Data
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I write a Datalog query to find all blocks with a specific tag in the DB version?

prompt_templates.title: Register Slash Commands
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I register a slash command and a block context menu item in my Logseq plugin?

prompt_templates.title: Handle Properties
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the differences in handling block properties between MD and DB versions of Logseq?

output_examples.input: How do I create a Logseq plugin that queries pages tagged with 'Book'?
output: Create a plugin with package.json using the logseq manifest format
Initialize with logseq.ready() and register your queries
Use logseq.DB.datascriptQuery() with a Datalog query targeting :block/tags
Query example: Find blocks with 'Book' tag using entity-based queries
Display results using logseq.UI.showMsg() or create a custom UI
Test by loading unpacked plugin in Logseq developer mode

best_practices: Use feature detection to check if the graph is DB-based before executing version-specific code
Test plugins with both DB and MD graphs when supporting both versions
Follow the plugin structure convention with package.json, index.html, and README.md
anti_patterns: Hardcoding page names instead of using configurable settings
Assuming MD-style queries work in DB version without modification
Not handling the unified node model where pages and blocks are similar entities

faq.question: What is the difference between MD and DB versions of Logseq?
faq.answer: MD version uses file-based storage while DB version uses a Datascript database. DB version offers structured properties, typed values, and entity-based queries.

faq.question: What tools do I need to develop Logseq plugins?
faq.answer: Node.js and npm for package management, a code editor, and Logseq with developer mode enabled for testing.

faq.question: How do I load my plugin for testing?
faq.answer: Enable developer mode in Logseq settings, then go to Plugins and select 'Load unpacked plugin' to choose your plugin folder.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using Logseq plugins?
faq.answer: Plugins run in sandboxed iframes with limited API access. Review plugin permissions before installing third-party plugins.

faq.question: Why is my MD query not working in DB version?
faq.answer: DB version uses entity-based queries with :block/title instead of :block/content. Rewrite queries using Datalog syntax for the DB schema.

faq.question: How do I publish my plugin to the Logseq marketplace?
faq.answer: Build your plugin with npm run build, create a GitHub release, and submit your plugin to the Logseq Plugin Marketplace repository.
